message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Can Generative AI improve social science?
Paper Abstract: Generative AI that can produce realistic text, images, and other human-like outputs is currently transforming many different industries. Yet it is not yet known how such tools might influence social science research. I argue Generative AI has the potential to improve survey research, online experiments, automated content analyses, agent-based models, and other techniques commonly used to study human behavior. In the second section of this article, I discuss the many limitations of Generative AI. I examine how bias in the data used to train these tools can negatively impact social science research—as well as a range of other challenges related to ethics, replication, environmental impact, and the proliferation of low-quality research. I conclude by arguing that social scientists can address many of these limitations by creating open-source infrastructure for research on human behavior. Such infrastructure is not only necessary to ensure broad access to high-quality research tools, I argue, but also because the progress of AI will require deeper understanding of the social forces that guide human behavior.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Generative AI:

## Definition and Scope

Generative AI (or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

## Applications and Industries

Generative AI has been adopted in a variety of sectors, including software development, healthcare, finance, entertainment, customer service, sales and marketing, art, writing, and product design.

## Key Technologies and Models

Large language models (LLMs) like Gemini, Claude, and Copilot are designed to be capable of generating and understanding human language as well as being able to conduct a wide range of tasks.(no content)Generative AI software examples include ChatGPT, Midjourney, and DALL-E.

## Current Significance

As of 2025, ChatGPT remains the 4th most visited website, behind sites such as Google and Facebook.(no content)Half of Americans use LLMs.

## Concerns and Challenges

Generative AI has been used for cybercrime and to deceive and manipulate people through fake news and deepfakes. It may lead to mass replacement of human jobs, and the tools have been described as violating intellectual property laws, since they are trained on copyrighted works.

Generative AI has been adopted in a variety of sectors, including software development, healthcare, finance, entertainment, customer service, sales and marketing, art, writing, and product design.

## Key Technologies and Models

Large language models (LLMs) like Gemini, Claude, and Copilot are designed to be capable of generating and understanding human language as well as being able to conduct a wide range of tasks.(no content)Generative AI software examples include ChatGPT, Midjourney, and DALL-E.

## Current Significance

As of 2025, ChatGPT remains the 4th most visited website, behind sites such as Google and Facebook.(no content)Half of Americans use LLMs.

## Concerns and Challenges

Generative AI has been used for cybercrime and to deceive and manipulate people through fake news and deepfakes. It may lead to mass replacement of human jobs, and the tools have been described as violating intellectual property laws, since they are trained on copyrighted works.

Web search results for query: "Content analysis automated"

Links: [{"title":"Online content analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_content_analysis"},{"title":"Content analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_analysis"},{"title":"Video content analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_content_analysis"},{"title":"Automatic content recognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_content_recognition"},{"title":"Automatic indexing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_indexing"},{"title":"Semantic Visions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Visions"},{"title":"Automatic content extraction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_content_extraction"},{"title":"Computer-assisted qualitative data analysis software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer-assisted_qualitative_data_analysis_software"},{"title":"High-content screening - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-content_screening"},{"title":"Talk:Content analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Content_analysis"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about automated content analysis:

## Overview

Computers are increasingly used in content analysis to automate the labeling (or coding) of documents.(no content)Automatic content analysis represents a slight departure from traditional content analysis procedures in that human coders are being supplemented by a computational method, and some of these methods do not require categories to be defined in advance.

## Methods and Techniques

Simple computational techniques can provide descriptive data such as word frequencies and document lengths, while machine learning classifiers can greatly increase the number of texts that can be labeled.(no content)Two main categories of automatic textual analysis are identified: supervised and unsupervised methods. Supervised methods involve creating a coding scheme and manually coding a sub-sample of the documents that the researcher wants to analyze.(no content)Quantitative textual analysis models often employ 'bag of words' methods that remove word ordering, delete words that are very common and very uncommon, and simplify words through lemmatisation or stemming that reduces the dimensionality of the text by reducing complex words to their root word.

## Tools and Applications

Numerous computer-aided text analysis (CATA) computer programs are available that analyze text for predetermined linguistic, semantic, and psychological characteristics.

## Validation

Results of supervised methods can be validated by drawing a distinct sub-sample of the corpus, called a 'validation set', where documents can be hand-coded and compared to the automatic coding output to evaluate how well the algorithm replicated human coding.

I've completed the web search for "Experiment online behavioral." Here are the key findings:

## Web-Based Experiments

A web-based experiment or Internet-based experiment is an experiment that is conducted over the Internet.(no content)In such experiments, the Internet is either "a medium through which to target larger and more diverse samples with reduced administrative and financial costs" or "a field of social science research in its own right."

## Applications and Advantages

Psychology and Internet studies are probably the disciplines that have used these experiments most widely, although a range of other disciplines including political science and economics also use web-based experiments.(no content)This form of experimental setup has become increasingly popular because researchers can cheaply collect large amounts of data from a wider range of locations and people.

One notable example is an online field experiment conducted on 61 million Facebook users tested whether receiving information about voting, polling places, and the voting behavior of one's friends led individuals to seek out political information, influenced political self-expression, and changed real-world voting behavior.

## Validity and Limitations

Because participants remain in their homes or offices while participating in the experiment, scholars have also argued that such experiments have greater ecological validity. However, web-based experiments may have weaker experimental controls compared to laboratory-based experiments, and may face greater difficulties coming up with procedures that ensure reliability and internal validity.

I've performed a web search on human behavior psychology. Here's what I found:

## Overview of Psychology and Human Behavior

Psychology is the scientific study of behavior and mind, with subject matter including the behavior of humans and nonhumans, both conscious and unconscious phenomena, and mental processes such as thoughts, feelings, and motives.

## Key Areas of Human Behavior Study

The study of human behavior is inherently interdisciplinary, drawing from psychology, sociology, anthropology, neuroscience, economics, political science, criminology, public health, and emerging fields like cyberpsychology and environmental psychology.

Different types of behavior studied include:

- Cognitive behavior involves mental processes of learning, memory, and decision-making, interconnected with psychological behavior that includes emotional regulation, mental health, and individual differences in personality and temperament.

- Social behavior is behavior among two or more organisms within the same species, it encompasses any behavior in which one member affects another.

- Developmental behavior changes across the human lifespan from infancy through aging, while organizational behavior governs conduct in workplace and institutional settings.

## Key Perspectives

The nature versus nurture debate remains central to understanding human behavior, examining the relative contributions of genetic predispositions and environmental influences.(no content)Contemporary research increasingly recognizes the complex interactions between biological, psychological, social, cultural, and environmental factors that shape behavioral outcomes.

Human behavior psychology encompasses many specialized fields and continues to evolve with modern research recognizing the intricate interplay of multiple factors influencing how people behave.

I've performed a web search on human behavior psychology. Here's what I found:

## Overview of Psychology and Human Behavior

Psychology is the scientific study of behavior and mind, with subject matter including the behavior of humans and nonhumans, both conscious and unconscious phenomena, and mental processes such as thoughts, feelings, and motives.

## Key Areas of Human Behavior Study

The study of human behavior is inherently interdisciplinary, drawing from psychology, sociology, anthropology, neuroscience, economics, political science, criminology, public health, and emerging fields like cyberpsychology and environmental psychology.

Different types of behavior studied include:

- Cognitive behavior involves mental processes of learning, memory, and decision-making, interconnected with psychological behavior that includes emotional regulation, mental health, and individual differences in personality and temperament.

- Social behavior is behavior among two or more organisms within the same species, it encompasses any behavior in which one member affects another.

- Developmental behavior changes across the human lifespan from infancy through aging, while organizational behavior governs conduct in workplace and institutional settings.

## Key Perspectives

The nature versus nurture debate remains central to understanding human behavior, examining the relative contributions of genetic predispositions and environmental influences.(no content)Contemporary research increasingly recognizes the complex interactions between biological, psychological, social, cultural, and environmental factors that shape behavioral outcomes.

Human behavior psychology encompasses many specialized fields and continues to evolve with modern research recognizing the intricate interplay of multiple factors influencing how people behave.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of social science research methodology:

## Definition and Core Approaches

Social research is research conducted by social scientists following a systematic plan.(no content)Social research methodologies can be classified as quantitative and qualitative.(no content)Quantitative designs approach social phenomena through quantifiable evidence, and often rely on statistical analyses of many cases (or across intentionally designed treatments in an experiment) to create valid and reliable general claims.(no content)Qualitative designs emphasize understanding of social phenomena through direct observation, communication with participants, or analyses of texts, and may stress contextual subjective accuracy over generality.

## Research Methods

Social scientists employ a range of methods in order to analyze a vast breadth of social phenomena: from analyzing census survey data derived from millions of individuals, to conducting in-depth analysis of a single agent's social experiences; from monitoring what is happening on contemporary streets, to investigating historical documents.(no content)Empirical methods include survey research, statistical analysis or econometrics, case studies, experiments, and model building.

## Contemporary Practice

In modern academic practice, researchers are often eclectic, using multiple methodologies (combining both quantitative and qualitative research).(no content)While very different in many aspects, both qualitative and quantitative approaches involve a systematic interaction between theory and data.

## Goals of Social Research

Social research attempts to create or validate theories through data collection and data analysis, and its goal is exploration, description, explanation, and prediction.

Web search results for query: "Agent-based model"

Links: [{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Agent-based model in biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model_in_biology"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Agent-based modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Agent-based_modeling&redirect=no"},{"title":"GAMA Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAMA_Platform"},{"title":"Sugarscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarscape"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about agent-based models:

## Definition and Core Concept

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.

## How They Work

Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena. A key principle is emergence: The process is one of emergence, which some express as "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts". In other words, higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.

## Key Components

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales (typically referred to as agent-granularity); (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.(no content)Individual agents are typically characterized as boundedly rational, presumed to be acting in what they perceive as their own interests, such as reproduction, economic benefit, or social status, using heuristics or simple decision-making rules.

## Implementation and History

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.(no content)The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s. Since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

## Applications

Agent-based models have diverse applications across multiple fields including biology, economics, social sciences, and environmental management. Agent-based models can be used to simulate a wide variety of social phenomena, including transportation, market failures, cooperation and escalation and spreading of conflicts.

Web search results for query: "Survey methodology research"

Links: [{"title":"Survey methodology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_methodology"},{"title":"Survey (human research) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_(human_research)"},{"title":"Survey Research Methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_Research_Methods"},{"title":"Descriptive research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Descriptive_research"},{"title":"Qualitative research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qualitative_research"},{"title":"National Crime Victimization Survey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Crime_Victimization_Survey"},{"title":"Field research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_research"},{"title":"Questionnaire - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Questionnaire"},{"title":"Snowball sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowball_sampling"},{"title":"Scarborough Research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scarborough_Research"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about survey methodology research:

## Definition and Scope

Survey methodology is a field of applied statistics concentrating on human-research surveys, and studies the sampling of individual units from a population and associated techniques of survey data collection, such as questionnaire construction and methods for improving the number and accuracy of responses.

## Core Principles

Since survey research is almost always based on a sample of the population, the success of the research is dependent on the representativeness of the sample with respect to a target population of interest to the researcher.(no content)Survey methodology as a scientific field seeks to identify principles about the sample design, data collection instruments, statistical adjustment of data, and data processing, and final data analysis that can create systematic and random survey errors.

## Survey Design Types

The three general types of survey designs are cross-sectional, successive independent samples, and longitudinal studies.(no content)In cross-sectional studies, a sample (or samples) is drawn from the relevant population and studied once, and a cross-sectional study describes characteristics of that population at one time, but cannot give any insight as to the causes of population characteristics.

## Data Collection Methods

Surveys may be conducted by phone, mail, via the internet, and also in person in public spaces.(no content)Surveys are used to gather or gain knowledge in fields such as social research and demography.

## Questionnaire Development

A questionnaire is a research instrument that consists of a set of questions (or other types of prompts) for the purpose of gathering information from respondents through survey or statistical study.(no content)One key concern with questionnaires is that they may contain quite large measurement errors, and the exact formulation of a survey question and its scale is crucial, since they affect the level of measurement error.

Links: [{"title":"Survey methodology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_methodology"},{"title":"Survey (human research) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_(human_research)"},{"title":"Survey Research Methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_Research_Methods"},{"title":"Descriptive research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Descriptive_research"},{"title":"Qualitative research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qualitative_research"},{"title":"National Crime Victimization Survey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Crime_Victimization_Survey"},{"title":"Field research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_research"},{"title":"Questionnaire - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Questionnaire"},{"title":"Snowball sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowball_sampling"},{"title":"Scarborough Research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scarborough_Research"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about survey methodology research:

## Definition and Scope

Survey methodology is a field of applied statistics concentrating on human-research surveys, and studies the sampling of individual units from a population and associated techniques of survey data collection, such as questionnaire construction and methods for improving the number and accuracy of responses.

## Core Principles

Since survey research is almost always based on a sample of the population, the success of the research is dependent on the representativeness of the sample with respect to a target population of interest to the researcher.(no content)Survey methodology as a scientific field seeks to identify principles about the sample design, data collection instruments, statistical adjustment of data, and data processing, and final data analysis that can create systematic and random survey errors.

## Survey Design Types

The three general types of survey designs are cross-sectional, successive independent samples, and longitudinal studies.(no content)In cross-sectional studies, a sample (or samples) is drawn from the relevant population and studied once, and a cross-sectional study describes characteristics of that population at one time, but cannot give any insight as to the causes of population characteristics.

## Data Collection Methods

Surveys may be conducted by phone, mail, via the internet, and also in person in public spaces.(no content)Surveys are used to gather or gain knowledge in fields such as social research and demography.

## Questionnaire Development

A questionnaire is a research instrument that consists of a set of questions (or other types of prompts) for the purpose of gathering information from respondents through survey or statistical study.(no content)One key concern with questionnaires is that they may contain quite large measurement errors, and the exact formulation of a survey question and its scale is crucial, since they affect the level of measurement error.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Can Generative AI improve social science?" Here's a summary of what was extracted:

## Paper Classification: **Contribution**

The paper proposes new approaches and infrastructure for improving social science research using generative AI, making it a contribution paper.

## Extracted Triples (7 entities):

| Entity | Relation | Type | Relevance |
|--------|----------|------|-----------|
| Generative artificial intelligence | uses | artifact | The paper explores how generative AI models can be applied to improve social science research methods. |
| Survey methodology | proposes | task | The paper proposes improvements to survey research through the application of generative AI. |
| Web-based experiments | proposes | task | The paper suggests generative AI can improve online experiments for studying human behavior. |
| Content analysis | proposes | method | The paper proposes automated content analysis as a technique that can be enhanced by generative AI. |
| Agent-based model | proposes | method | The paper proposes that generative AI can improve agent-based modeling techniques used in social science. |
| Social research | proposes | task | The paper proposes new approaches and infrastructure for social science research using generative AI. |
| Human behavior | uses | concept | Understanding human behavior is the core subject of social science research that the paper aims to improve. |

The validation passed successfully with all requirements met:
- ✅ Paper has at least 1 "uses" relation (Generative AI and Human behavior)
- ✅ Contribution paper has multiple "proposes" relations
- ✅ All Wikipedia URLs are valid and properly formatted
- ✅ All entity types are correctly classified

Sources:
- [Generative artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_artificial_intelligence)
- [Survey methodology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_methodology)
- [Web-based experiments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web-based_experiments)
- [Content analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_analysis)
- [Agent-based model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model)
- [Social research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_research)
- [Human behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_behavior)
